Info.title: How to Make a Complex REST Api using React, Spring Boot and MySQL
Info.desc: Describes how to make a complex REST Api with React, Spring Boot, and MySQL.

Instructions.instruction: We are going to build a full-stack web application step-by-step using React, Java, Spring Boot, and MySQL.
A full video demo of this app can be found on my YouTube channel [here](FILL THIS LINK IN).
Let's get started!

Info.title: Technologies We'll Use
Info.desc: This is the tech stack we'll use to make this project

Instructions.instruction: React - The JavaScript Framework we'll use to build our user interface.
JavaScript - The scripting language we'll use to add logic to our frontend.
TypeScript - The programming language we'll for some parts of our frontend. It's a superset of JavaScript with types.
Spring Boot - The Python web framework we'll use to help build our Rest Api.
Java - The programming language we'll use to develop our Rest Api.
SQL - The language we'll use to help build and query our database.
MySQL - The database we'll use to store user information.
Visual Studio Code - The code editor we'll use to help us build our project.
JUnit - The Python testing framework we'll use to test our Rest Api.
Mockito - A mocking framework used in unit testing to mock objects and their behaviors.
Jest - The JavaScript testing framework we'll use to test our Vue code. I'm basically just including it to show you how to set it up with TypeScript.
Github - The platform we'll use for version control and collaborative software development.
Git - The distributed version control system we'll use to track changes to our projects.
Homebrew - MacOS package manager we'll use to install software. Optional to use.
JWT - Stands for JSON Web Token. We'll use it to securely
openssl - The library we'll use to generate a secure key for JWT.
jq - Stands for "JSON Query". We'll use it to pretty print JSON data in our terminal.

Info.title: How to Setup Java 17
Info.desc: Explains how to install and setup Java 17.

Instructions.instruction: Download it [here](https://www.oracle.com/java/technologies/downloads/#jdk17-mac) if you don't already installed. Make sure to choose the right version for your OS and architecture. Run the following command to determine your architecture. When you're back on the site, choose the DMG installer. Then click on the download button and then follow the prompts.

Code.FormatCode: uname -m
Code.CopyCode: uname -m

Instructions.instruction: Now go to your terminal and run the following command. We're going to set your Java version to 17. Note that this process is different for bash.

Code.FormatCode: nano ~/.zshrc
Code.CopyCode: nano ~/.zshrc

Instructions.instruction: In your nano file paste the two following lines. You shouldn't have to modify them.

Code.FormatCode:
export JAVA_HOME=/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk-17.jdk/Contents/Home
export PATH=$JAVA_HOME/bin:$PATH
Code.CopyCode:
export JAVA_HOME=/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk-17.jdk/Contents/Home
export PATH=$JAVA_HOME/bin:$PATH

Instructions.instruction: To save the changes, press control + o. Then press return/enter. Then press control + x.
Open a completely new terminal and run the following command. It should output Java 17.0.6 (Or 17 something)

Code.FormatCode: java --version
Code.CopyCode: java --version

Instructions.instruction: After you have Java 17 installed, delete the archive that contains the installation files.
Congratulations! You should now have Java 17 setup on your computer.

Instructions.instruction: Now open a terminal and run the following commands to create a new file in the root directory called "start.sh".

Code.FormatCode:
cd Superhero-Rest-Api
touch start.sh
Code.CopyCode:
cd Superhero-Rest-Api
touch start.sh

Instructions.instruction: Open the "start.sh" file and paste in the following code.

Code.FormatCode:
#!/bin/sh
YELLOW='\033[0;33m'
BLUE='\033[0;34m'
NC='\033[0m' # No Color

kill_port_8080() {
  PID=$(lsof -t -i:8080)

  if [ -n "$PID" ]; then
    echo "\n${BLUE}Port 8080 is in use by PID $PID. Stopping the process...${NC}"
    kill -9 $PID
    echo "${BLUE}Process $PID has been stopped.${NC}"
  fi
}


stop_spring_boot() {
  echo "\n\n${YELLOW}Spring Boot application finished successfully! Stopping Spring Boot...${NC}"
  kill "$SPRING_BOOT_PID" 2>/dev/null

  kill_port_8080
}

# Handles control + c (SIGINT)/termination (SIGTERM)
trap stop_spring_boot INT TERM

kill_port_8080

# Runs the Gradle bootRun task in the background
./gradlew --quiet bootRun &
SPRING_BOOT_PID=$!

sleep 0.1

echo "\n* Running on ${BLUE}http://localhost:8080${NC}\n"

# Wait for the Spring Boot process to finish
wait "$SPRING_BOOT_PID"
Code.CopyCode:
#!/bin/sh

NC='\033[0m' # No Color

  if [ -n "$PID" ]; then
    echo "\n${BLUE}Port 8080 is in use by PID $PID. Stopping the process...${NC}"

stop_spring_boot() {

# Handles control + c (SIGINT)/termination (SIGTERM)

SPRING_BOOT_PID=$!

sleep 0.1

Instructions.instruction: Now go to your terminal and run the following command.

Code.FormatCode: nano ~/.zshrc
Code.CopyCode: nano ~/.zshrc

Instructions.instruction: Paste the following shell code at the bottom of the file. Note that "gradle" is just a variable, it's not associated with the actual gradle tool.

Code.FormatCode:
gradle() {
    RED='\033[0;31m'
    NC='\033[0m'

    if [ "$1" = "run" ]; then
        if [ -f "./start.sh" ]; then
            ./start.sh
        else
            echo -e "${RED}Error: ./start.sh not found. Change into your Rest Api folder.${NC}"
        fi
    fi
}
Code.CopyCode:
gradle() {
    RED='\033[0;31m'
    NC='\033[0m'

    if [ "$1" = "run" ]; then
        if [ -f "./start.sh" ]; then
            ./start.sh
        else
            echo -e "${RED}Error: ./start.sh not found. Change into your Rest Api folder.${NC}"
        fi
    fi
}

Code.CopyCode: source ~/.zshrc

Instructions.instruction: We did this because gradle doesn't have a way to detect SIGTERM exit signals. We just made the terminal command "gradle run" which will allow us to run the shell script completely separated from the gradle process.

Info.title: Design Your Database Schema
Info.desc: The first thing we'll do is design our database ER and Schema diagrams.

Instructions.instruction: We'll be creating a Superhero app. We'll have users that each have their own set of superheros. Each Superhero will have their own individual powers.

To make our diagrams we'll use [drawsql.app](https://drawsql.app/). If you don't already have an account, you can register using this [link](https://drawsql.app/register). When prompted to enter a team just write whatever you want.
A cool feature of drawsql.app is that you convert SQL to a schema diagram and a schema diagram to SQL.
You download the Schema diagram &here&(/download/SuperheroSchema.png) for future reference.

Info.title: Create the Tables in MySQL
Info.desc: Explains how to create your databases in MySQL

Instructions.instruction: First login to MySQL by opening your terminal and running the following command. Enter your password when prompted.

Code.FormatCode: mysql -u root -p
Code.CopyCode: mysql -u root -p

Instructions.instruction: Create your regular database and your test base with these SQL queries

Code.FormatCode:
CREATE DATABASE superhero_db;
CREATE DATABASE superhero_test_db;
Code.CopyCode:
CREATE DATABASE superhero_db;
CREATE DATABASE superhero_test_db;

Instructions.instruction: Create your users with the following SQL commands. Replace the values of the strings at the end with your actual passwords. Choose any password you want. I'd recommend keeping them simple and recording them somewhere. However make sure they are over 8 chars long, have mixed case, and special chars.

Code.FormatCode:
CREATE USER 'superhero_user'@'%' IDENTIFIED BY 'your_password_here';
CREATE USER 'superhero_test_user'@'%' IDENTIFIED BY 'your_password_here';
Code.CopyCode:
CREATE USER 'superhero_user'@'%' IDENTIFIED BY 'your_password_here';
CREATE USER 'superhero_test_user'@'%' IDENTIFIED BY 'your_password_here';

Instructions.instruction: Grant privileges to those users.

Code.FormatCode:
GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON superhero_db.* TO 'superhero_user'@'%';
GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON superhero_test_db.* TO 'superhero_test_user'@'%';
Code.CopyCode:
GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON superhero_db.* TO 'superhero_user'@'%';
GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON superhero_test_db.* TO 'superhero_test_user'@'%';

Instructions.instruction: Apply the privileges after you're done.

Code.FormatCode: FLUSH PRIVILEGES;
Code.CopyCode: FLUSH PRIVILEGES;

Instructions.instruction: Exit the session using the following command.

Code.FormatCode: EXIT;
Code.CopyCode: EXIT;

Instructions.instruction: Now we're going to create our tables First we'll sign in as the main "superhero_user" and populate superhero_db. Enter your password when prompted.

Code.FormatCode: mysql -u superhero_user -p superhero_db
Code.CopyCode: mysql -u superhero_user -p superhero_db

Instructions.instruction: Run the following SQL query to create the tables.

Code.FormatCode:
CREATE TABLE users (
    user_id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
    name VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL,
    role VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
    username VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL UNIQUE,
    hashed_password VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL
);


CREATE TABLE superheroes (
    super_id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
    name VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL,
    real_name VARCHAR(100),
    universe VARCHAR(100),
    year_created INT,
    can_delete BOOL
);


-- One-to-One relationship with superhero 
CREATE TABLE images (
    image_id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
    original_filename VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    stored_filename VARCHAR(255),
    super_id INT UNIQUE,
    FOREIGN KEY (super_id) REFERENCES superheroes(super_id) ON DELETE CASCADE
);


CREATE TABLE powers (
    power_id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
    name VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL
);

-- Many-to-Many Relationship Between superhero and power
CREATE TABLE superhero_powers (
    super_id INT,
    power_id INT,
    PRIMARY KEY (super_id, power_id),
    FOREIGN KEY (super_id) REFERENCES superheroes(super_id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
    FOREIGN KEY (power_id) REFERENCES powers(power_id) ON DELETE CASCADE
);

-- Many-to-Many Relationship Between user and superhero
CREATE TABLE user_superheroes (
    id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
    user_id INT,
    super_id INT,
    FOREIGN KEY (user_id) REFERENCES users(user_id),
    FOREIGN KEY (super_id) REFERENCES superheroes(super_id)
);
Code.CopyCode:
CREATE TABLE users (
    user_id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
    name VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL,
    role VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL,
    username VARCHAR(50) NOT NULL UNIQUE,
    hashed_password VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL
);


CREATE TABLE superheroes (
    super_id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
    name VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL,
    real_name VARCHAR(100),
    universe VARCHAR(100),
    year_created INT,
    can_delete BOOL
);


-- One-to-One relationship with superhero 
CREATE TABLE images (
    image_id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
    original_filename VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL,
    stored_filename VARCHAR(255),
    super_id INT UNIQUE,
    FOREIGN KEY (super_id) REFERENCES superheroes(super_id) ON DELETE CASCADE
);


CREATE TABLE powers (
    power_id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
    name VARCHAR(100) NOT NULL
);

-- Many-to-Many Relationship Between superhero and power
CREATE TABLE superhero_powers (
    super_id INT,
    power_id INT,
    PRIMARY KEY (super_id, power_id),
    FOREIGN KEY (super_id) REFERENCES superheroes(super_id) ON DELETE CASCADE,
    FOREIGN KEY (power_id) REFERENCES powers(power_id) ON DELETE CASCADE
);

-- Many-to-Many Relationship Between user and superhero
CREATE TABLE user_superheroes (
    id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
    user_id INT,
    super_id INT,
    FOREIGN KEY (user_id) REFERENCES users(user_id),
    FOREIGN KEY (super_id) REFERENCES superheroes(super_id)
);

Instructions.instruction: Confirm they were created correctly using the following query. All 4 tables should show in the results.

Code.CopyCode: SHOW TABLES;

Instructions.instruction: Congratulations! You should now have the MySQL Database setup.
If you need to drop the databases and recreate them, use the following commands. Enter your password when prompted.
If you need to drop all the tables and repopulate them, login to your database then run the following commands.

Info.title: Create an S3 Bucket on AWS
Info.desc: We're going to create an S3 Bucket on AWS to store our images in the cloud.

Instructions.instruction: Before doing any of this make sure you've completed the &How to Setup an Amazon Web Services Account&[AWSLink] instruction set.
Go to the S3 console dashboard using this [link](https://s3.console.aws.amazon.com/s3/home). Sign in using root user email.
Once you've signed and go to the S3 console, press the orange "Create bucket" button.

In the "Create bucket" form, enter the following values. Leave everything that's not specified as default.

Scroll down a little to the "Bucket policy" section. Press the "Edit" button on the top-right.
In the Policy text area paste the following data. Then scroll down and press the "Save changes" button.
Congratulations! Your S3 bucket should now be created.

Instructions.instruction: Open your "superhero_aws_pics" in VSCode. Then paste the following code into the "upload_to_aws.py" file. Replace "YOUR_MYSQL_SUPERHERO_DB_PASSWORD" and the "YOUR_MYSQL_SUPERHERO_TEST_DB_PASSWORD" with your actual passwords.

Code.FormatCode:
import os
from PIL import Image
import mysql.connector
import boto3
import uuid

def get_file_paths(folder_path) -> list[str]:
    return [ os.path.join(folder_path, file_name) for file_name in os.listdir(folder_path) ]


def shrink_images():
    file_paths = get_file_paths('superhero_pics')

    for file_path in file_paths:
        img = Image.open(file_path)

        base_width = 800
        width_percent = (base_width / float(img.size[0]))
        new_height = int((float(img.size[1]) * float(width_percent)))

        resized_img = img.resize((base_width, new_height), Image.LANCZOS)

        name = os.path.basename(file_path).strip()

        resized_img.save(f'./resized_pics/{name}')


def upload_images_s3(mysql_creds: list) -> list[str]:

    s3 = boto3.resource('s3')

    shrink_images()

    creds = mysql_creds[0]

    connection = mysql.connector.connect(
            host='localhost',
            user=creds['username'],
            password=creds['password'],
            database=creds['database']
        )

    cursor = connection.cursor()

    cursor.execute("SELECT original_filename FROM images;")
    results = cursor.fetchall()

    file_paths = [f'resized_pics/{result[0]}' for result in results]

    print(file_paths)

    connection.commit()
    
    cursor.close()
    connection.close()
    

    new_filenames = []

    for file_path in file_paths:
        file_name = file_path.replace("resized_pics/", "")

        # Generates a new unique name for the file and keeps the same extension
        new_filename = uuid.uuid4().hex + "." + file_name.rsplit(".", 1)[1].lower()

        superhero_bucket = s3.Bucket("superhero-pics")

        # Open the file in binary mode so it can be uploaded 
        with open(file_path, 'rb') as file:
            superhero_bucket.upload_fileobj(file, new_filename)

        print(f"Uploaded {file_name} as {new_filename}")

        new_filenames.append(new_filename)
    
    return new_filenames


def update_databases(mysql_creds: list):
    aws_file_names = upload_images_s3(mysql_creds)

    for creds in mysql_creds:

        print(f"\nUpdating MySQL Database - \"{creds['database']}\"")

        connection = mysql.connector.connect(
            host='localhost',
            user=creds['username'],
            password=creds['password'],
            database=creds['database']
        )

        cursor = connection.cursor()

        cursor.execute("SELECT name FROM superheroes;")
        results = cursor.fetchall()

        superhero_names = [row[0] for row in results]
        superhero_dict = dict(zip(superhero_names, aws_file_names))
        
        
        for superhero_name, stored_filename in superhero_dict.items():
            update_query = """
                UPDATE images
                SET stored_filename = %s
                WHERE super_id = (SELECT super_id FROM superheroes WHERE name = %s);
            """

            cursor.execute(update_query, (stored_filename, superhero_name))

            print("MySQL database stored_filename updated successfully!")


        connection.commit()

        cursor.close()
        connection.close()



mysql_creds = [
    {
        "username": "superhero_user",
        "password": "YOUR_MYSQL_SUPERHERO_DB_PASSWORD",
        "database": "superhero_db"
    },
    {
        "username": "superhero_test_user",
        "password": "YOUR_MYSQL_SUPERHERO_TEST_DB_PASSWORD",
        "database": "superhero_test_db"
    }
]

update_databases(mysql_creds)

Info.title: Spring Boot API Folder Setup Explanation
Info.desc: Explains the purpose of the various folders and what code they should contain.

Instructions.instruction: config - Configuration Java files for the Rest API.

controllers - Where your endpoints will be stored. All data that's returned from this Rest API will happen in this folder. The logic and functions you use to "talk to" your database should be in your "services" and "repositories" folder. Keep your endpoint functions short and clean.
dto - Data transfer objects. Transfer data between layers of the application, particularly between the service layer and the presentation layer
exceptions - The custom exceptions for your project.

models - The data structures and classes that map to your database tables. Each entity represents a table in your database and each attribute of the entity corresponds to a field in the table.The data structures and classes that map to your database tables. Each entity represents a table in your database and each attribute of the entity corresponds to a field in the table.
repositories - Classes or interfaces that handle the SQL data access logic. Where CRUD operations are performed.
services - Functions that use your repository functions to create business logic in your application.
utils - Common functions that are reused in various parts of your Rest API.
test - Where our Junit tests will be.

Instructions.instruction:
In your .env file paste the following values.

1. Replace "YOUR-SUPERHERO-DB-PASSWORD" and "YOUR-SUPERHERO-TEST-DB-PASSWORD" with your actual passwords for the superhero_db and superhero_test_db databases. Note that "3306" is the default port used by MySQL database servers for client-server communication.

2. Replace "VALUE_FROM PREVIOUS STEP" with the openssl key you copied in the previous step.

3. Replace the value of "FRONTEND_URL" with your actual frontend localhost link if necessary. If your database password has % signs in it, replace them with %25 to escape them in your DEV_DATABASE_URI and TEST_DATABASE_URI urls.

Code.FormatCode:
SPRING_ENV=development

DEV_DATABASE_URI=jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/superhero_db?user=superhero_user&password=YOUR-SUPERHERO-DB-PASSWORD

TEST_DATABASE_URI=jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/superhero_test_db?user=superhero_test_user&password=YOUR-SUPERHERO-TEST-DB-PASSWORD

PROD_DATABASE_URI=NULL

JWT_SECRET_KEY=VALUE_FROM PREVIOUS STEP

FRONTEND_URL=http://localhost:5173

S3_BUCKET=superhero-pics

Instructions.instruction: Now we'll run our Rest API and test the endpoints.

Install the [Thunder Client](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=rangav.vscode-thunder-client) VSCode extension if you haven't already. It's basically Postman for VSCode and we're going to use it to ping our endpoints.

Once you have the extension installed go to the very top above VSCode and press the "File" button. In the drop-down select "New Window". This will open another VSCode window where you can use Thunder Client.
Go to your terminal in one of your VSCode windows and start running your API by using the following commands.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Superhero-Rest-Api
gradle run
Code.CopyCode:
cd Superhero-Rest-Api
gradle run

Instructions.instruction: Now go to your second VSCode window and open Thunder Client by clicking on the symbol of the left-hand side that looks like a circle with a thunderbolt throught it. Then click the blue "New Request" to open a new dashboard.
The very first thing we'll do is authenticate as admin. Press the "Body" tab and paste the following JSON data in the text area. Press "command + s" to save.
Now in the top field paste in the following link and set the request type to "POST". Then press send

Code.FormatCode:
POST http://localhost:8080/api/users/authenticate

*Press Send*
Code.CopyCode:
POST http://localhost:8080/api/users/authenticate

*Press Send*

Instructions.instruction: In the response copy and record the value of the jwtToken attribute. You'll need it in the next step
Go to the "Headers" tab. Set all the headers and their values. Replace "JWT-TOKEN" with your jwtToken from the previous step.

Code.FormatCode:
Accept: */*
User-Agent: Thunder Client (https://www.thunderclient.com)
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer JWT-TOKEN

* Press command + s to save *
Code.CopyCode:
Accept: */*
User-Agent: Thunder Client (https://www.thunderclient.com)
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer JWT-TOKEN

* Press command + s to save *

Instructions.instruction: Go back up to the field and enter the following URL. Set the HTTP request, then press send. Do that for both requests. These two endpoints can only be accessed by the admin. The 2nd one will delete the user with id 6 in the database.

Code.FormatCode:
GET http://localhost:8080/api/users/all

* Press Send *

DELETE http://localhost:8080/api/users/6

* Press Send *
Code.CopyCode:
GET http://localhost:8080/api/users/all

DELETE http://localhost:8080/api/users/6

Instructions.instruction: Now we'll log in as a User instead of Admin. Go back to the "Body" tab. Delete the current data and paste in the new JSON.
Now in the field enter the following link and press send. Make sure it's a POST request.

Code.FormatCode:
POST http://localhost:8080/api/users/authenticate

*Press Send*
Code.CopyCode:
POST http://localhost:8080/api/users/authenticate

*Press Send*

Instructions.instruction: In the response copy and record the new value of the jwtToken. Then go to the "Headers" tab and replace the old token with the new one in the "Authorization" header. Replace "NEW-JWT-TOKEN" with the new one.

Code.FormatCode:
Authorization: Bearer NEW-JWT-TOKEN

* Press command + s to save *
Code.CopyCode:
Authorization: Bearer NEW-JWT-TOKEN

* Press command + s to save *

Instructions.instruction: You can do steps 97-99 using Postman for free. This [video](https://youtu.be/S7bwkys6D0E?si=1-8i40mZa14Rva1z) explains how to upload a file in a POST request.

I'll show how to run add superhero request in terminal since you'd need the paid version of Thunder client or Postman downloaded to upload it. I also thought it'd be good to show how the terminal command would work.

Open a new terminal and run the following command.

Replace "/Users/YOURUSERNAME/path/to/image/Picture.jpg" with an actual image path from your computer.

Replace "JWT-TOKEN" with your actual jwtToken.

Code.FormatCode:
curl -X POST \
-F "name=Bat2" \
-F "realName=Delete this" \
-F "universe=Marvel" \
-F "yearCreated=1991" \
-F "canDelete=true" \
-F "powerIds=3" \
-F "powerIds=2" \
-F "image=@/Users/YOURUSERNAME/path/to/image/Picture.jpg" \
-H "Authorization: Bearer JWT-TOKEN" \
http://localhost:8080/superheroes/users/2/superheroes/add
Code.CopyCode:
curl -X POST \
-F "name=Bat2" \
-F "realName=Delete this" \
-F "universe=Marvel" \
-F "yearCreated=1991" \
-F "canDelete=true" \
-F "powerIds=3" \
-F "powerIds=2" \
-F "image=@/Users/YOURUSERNAME/path/to/image/Picture.jpg" \
-H "Authorization: Bearer JWT-TOKEN" \
http://localhost:8080/superheroes/users/2/superheroes/add

Info.title: React Website Folder Setup Explanation
Info.desc: Explanation of the folders that will be used for your frontend code.

Instructions.instruction: src/api - Functions used to call and interact with your backend Rest API endpoints. It's a similar concept to the repository functions interacting with the database. Low-level database logic.
src/assets - Where you'll put things like your pictures, data, etc.
src/components - Components that you can use in your views. An example would a Note card.
src/lib - Where you'll put the link to where your backend Rest API is being hosted. For this project it should probably be something like "http://127.0.0.1:5000" in development.
src/router - The paths of your application. Used to navigate between pages in your application.
src/services - Business logic for your api functions. High-level logic and business rules.
src/states - A management system you can use to store data and methods you can use to modify and interact with it. It's pretty similar to a class.
src/styles - Where your CSS styles will be kept for the views and the components.
src/tests - Where your jest tests will be held for the application.
src/utils - Common functions that are used across various views.
src/views - The pages of your application. The components will be used in these views.
public - Where to store things like videos and files that the user can download.

Open the "SignIn.test.js" file and paste in the following code. This is how we'll test our code using Jest.
Push your changes to GitHub.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Superhero-Frontend
git add .
git commit -m "Testing"
git push
Code.CopyCode:
cd Superhero-Frontend
git add .
git commit -m "Testing"
git push

Instructions.instruction: Now open a terminal and run your tests using the following commands.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Superhero-Frontend
npm test
Code.CopyCode:
cd Superhero-Frontend
npm test

Instructions.instruction: A test-report.html file should've been created in the previous command. Use the following command to open it in your browser.

Code.FormatCode: open test-report.html
Code.CopyCode: open test-report.html

Instructions.instruction: Now close all your terminals.
Open a new terminal and run your Rest Api using the following commands.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Superhero-Rest-Api
gradle run
Code.CopyCode:
cd Superhero-Rest-Api
gradle run

Instructions.instruction: Keep the other terminal running, but open a second one. Use the following commands to run your React app.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Superhero-Frontend
npm run dev
Code.CopyCode:
cd Superhero-Frontend
npm run dev

Instructions.instruction: Try out the features of the website. Register a new user, then add superheroes, add team superheroes, etc.
Sign out and then sign in as an existing user with the following credentials. Then just try out features on the website.

Code.FormatCode:
john_doe
password1
Code.CopyCode:
john_doe
password1

Instructions.instruction: After you're done, go back to the terminal running your rest api. Press "control + c" to stop the process then close then terminal. Then go to the terminal running your frontend and close it.
Now login to your database and run the following commands and queries to see your changes. Enter your password when prompted.
Now run your frontend using the following commands.

Code.FormatCode:
cd Superhero-Frontend
npm run dev
Code.CopyCode:
cd Superhero-Frontend
npm run dev
